titleStmt.title: An almond for a parrat, or Cutbert Curry-knaues almes Fit for the knaue Martin, and the rest of those impudent beggers, that can not be content to stay their stomakes with a benefice, but they will needes breake their fastes with our bishops. Risum sum plenus. Therefore beware (gentle reader) you catch not the hicket with laughing.
titleStmt.author: Nash, Thomas, 1567-1601.
Lyly, John, 1554?-1606, attributed name.

publicationStmt.publisher: By the assignes of Signior Some-body [i.e. Eliot's Court Press?], and are to be sold at his shoppe in Trouble-knaue Stréet, at the signe of the Standish,
publicationStmt.pubPlace: Imprinted at a place, not farre from a place [i.e. London?] :

notesStmt.note: Attributed to Thomas Nash; sometimes also attributed to John Lyly.
A pamphlet in the Marprelate controversy.
The imprint is fictitious; printed at London by Eliot's Court Press, 1589? (STC).
Reproduction of the original in Harvard University. Library.

place.placeName: his shoppe in Trouble-knaue Stréet, at the signe of the Standish
